title: Authors and Citation
text: Capitaine L (2024). LongituRF: Random Forests Longitudinal Data. R package version 0.9.
code: @Manual{,   title = {LongituRF: Random Forests for Longitudinal Data},   author = {Louis Capitaine},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.9}, }

title: Random Forests for Longitudinal Data
text: goal LongituRF implements Random forests longitudinal data using stochastic semiparametric miced-model

title: Random Forests for Longitudinal Data
text: can install development version LongituRF GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("sistm/LongituRF")

title: Random Forests for Longitudinal Data
text: Simulate longitudinal data according semi-parametric stochastic mixed-effects model Train SMERF model generated data. take ~ 50 seconds data generated Brownian motion, use parameter sto=“BM” specify Brownian motion stochastic process fitted random forest (obtained last iteration). predicted random effects individual. predicted stochastic processes.  OOB error iteration.

title: Longitudinal data generator — DataLongGenerator
text: Simulate longitudinal data according semi-parametric stochastic mixed-effects model given : $$Y_i(t)=f(X_i(t))+Z_i(t)\beta_i + \omega_i(t)+\epsilon_i$$ \(Y_i(t)\) output time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(X_i(t)\) input predictors (fixed effects) time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(Z_i(t)\) random effects time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(\omega_i(t)\) Brownian motion volatility \(\gamma^2=0.8\) time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(\epsilon_i\) residual error variance \(\sigma^2=0.5\). data simulated according simulations low dimensional low dimensional scheme paper doi:10.1177/0962280220946080

title: Longitudinal data generator — DataLongGenerator
code: DataLongGenerator(n = 50, p = 6, G = 6)

title: Longitudinal data generator — DataLongGenerator
text: n numeric: Number individuals. default value n=50. p numeric: Number predictors. default value p=6. G numeric: Number groups predictors temporal behavior, generates p-G input variables temporal behavior.

title: Longitudinal data generator — DataLongGenerator
text: list following elements: Y: vector output trajectories. X : matrix fixed-effects predictors. Z: matrix random-effects predictors. id:  vector identifiers individual. time:  vector time measurements individual.

title: Longitudinal data generator — DataLongGenerator
code: oldpar <- par() oldopt <- options() data <- DataLongGenerator(n=17, p=6,G=6) # Generate the data # Let's see the output : w <- which(data$id==1) plot(data$time[w],data$Y[w],type="l",ylim=c(min(data$Y),max(data$Y)), col="grey") for (i in unique(data$id)){   w <- which(data$id==i)   lines(data$time[w],data$Y[w], col='grey') }  # Let's see the fixed effects predictors: par(mfrow=c(2,3), mar=c(2,3,3,2)) for (i in 1:ncol(data$X)){   w <- which(data$id==1)   plot(data$time[w],data$X[w,i], col="grey",ylim=c(min(data$X[,i]),   max(data$X[,i])),xlim=c(1,max(data$time)),main=latex2exp::TeX(paste0("$X^{(",i,")}$")))   for (k in unique(data$id)){     w <- which(data$id==k)     lines(data$time[w],data$X[w,i], col="grey")   } }  par(oldpar) #> Warning: graphical parameter "cin" cannot be set #> Warning: graphical parameter "cra" cannot be set #> Warning: graphical parameter "csi" cannot be set #> Warning: graphical parameter "cxy" cannot be set #> Warning: graphical parameter "din" cannot be set #> Warning: graphical parameter "page" cannot be set options(oldopt)

title: (S)MERF algorithm — MERF
text: (S)MERF adaptation random forest regression method longitudinal data introduced Hajjem et. al. (2014) doi:10.1080/00949655.2012.741599. model improved Capitaine et. al. (2020) doi:10.1177/0962280220946080 addition stochastic process. algorithm estimate parameters following semi-parametric stochastic mixed-effects model: $$Y_i(t)=f(X_i(t))+Z_i(t)\beta_i + \omega_i(t)+\epsilon_i$$ \(Y_i(t)\) output time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(X_i(t)\) input predictors (fixed effects) time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(Z_i(t)\) random effects time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(\omega_i(t)\) stochastic process time \(t\) \(\)th individual model serial correlations output measurements; \(\epsilon_i\) residual error.

title: (S)MERF algorithm — MERF
code: MERF(   X,   Y,   id,   Z,   iter = 100,   mtry = ceiling(ncol(X)/3),   ntree = 500,   time,   sto,   delta = 0.001 )

title: (S)MERF algorithm — MERF
text: X matrix: Nxp matrix containing p predictors fixed effects, column codes predictor. Y vector: vector containing output trajectories. id vector: vector identifiers different trajectories. Z matrix: Nxq matrix containing q predictor random effects. iter numeric: Maximal number iterations algorithm. default set iter=100 mtry numeric: Number variables randomly sampled candidates split. default value p/3. ntree numeric: Number trees grow. set small number, ensure every input row gets predicted least times. default value ntree=500. time vector: vector measurement times associated trajectories Y,Z X. sto character: Defines covariance function stochastic process, can either "none" stochastic process, "BM" Brownian motion, OrnUhl standard Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process, BBridge Brownian Bridge, fbm Fractional Brownian motion; can also function defined user. delta numeric: algorithm stops difference log likelihood two iterations smaller delta. default value set O.O01

title: (S)MERF algorithm — MERF
text: fitted (S)MERF model list following elements: forest: Random forest obtained last iteration. random_effects : Predictions random effects different trajectories. id_btilde: Identifiers individuals associated predictions random_effects. var_random_effects:  Estimation variance covariance matrix random effects. sigma_sto:  Estimation volatility parameter stochastic process. sigma:  Estimation residual variance parameter. time:  vector measurement times associated trajectories Y,Z X. sto:  Stochastic process used model. Vraisemblance: Log-likelihood different iterations. id:  Vector identifiers different trajectories. OOB:  OOB error fitted random forest iteration.

title: (S)MERT algorithm — MERT
text: (S)MERT adaptation random forest regression method longitudinal data introduced Hajjem et. al. (2011) doi:10.1016/j.spl.2010.12.003. model improved Capitaine et. al. (2020) doi:10.1177/0962280220946080 addition stochastic process. algorithm estimate parameters following semi-parametric stochastic mixed-effects model: $$Y_i(t)=f(X_i(t))+Z_i(t)\beta_i + \omega_i(t)+\epsilon_i$$ \(Y_i(t)\) output time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(X_i(t)\) input predictors (fixed effects) time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(Z_i(t)\) random effects time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(\omega_i(t)\) stochastic process time \(t\) \(\)th individual model serial correlations output measurements; \(\epsilon_i\) residual error.

title: (S)MERT algorithm — MERT
code: MERT(X, Y, id, Z, iter = 100, time, sto, delta = 0.001)

title: (S)MERT algorithm — MERT
text: X matrix: Nxp matrix containing p predictors fixed effects, column codes predictor. Y vector: vector containing output trajectories. id vector: vector identifiers different trajectories. Z matrix: Nxq matrix containing q predictor random effects. iter numeric: Maximal number iterations algorithm. default set iter=100 time vector: vector measurement times associated trajectories Y,Z X. sto character: Defines covariance function stochastic process, can either "none" stochastic process, "BM" Brownian motion, OrnUhl standard Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process, BBridge Brownian Bridge, fbm Fractional Brownian motion; can also function defined user. delta numeric: algorithm stops difference log likelihood two iterations smaller delta. default value set O.O01

title: (S)MERT algorithm — MERT
text: fitted (S)MERF model list following elements: forest: Tree obtained last iteration. random_effects : Predictions random effects different trajectories. id_btilde: Identifiers individuals associated predictions random_effects. var_random_effects:  Estimation variance covariance matrix random effects. sigma_sto:  Estimation volatility parameter stochastic process. sigma:  Estimation residual variance parameter. time:  vector measurement times associated trajectories Y,Z X. sto:  Stochastic process used model. Vraisemblance: Log-likelihood different iterations. id:  Vector identifiers different trajectories.

code: Moy(id, Btilde, sigmahat, Phi, Y, Z)

code: Moy_exp(id, Btilde, sigmahat, Phi, Y, Z, alpha, time, sigma2)

code: Moy_fbm(id, Btilde, sigmahat, Phi, Y, Z, H, time, sigma2)

title: Title — Moy_sto
code: Moy_sto(id, Btilde, sigmahat, Phi, Y, Z, sto, time, sigma2)

title: (S)REEMforest algorithm — REEMforest
code: REEMforest(   X,   Y,   id,   Z,   iter = 100,   mtry,   ntree = 500,   time,   sto,   delta = 0.001 )

title: (S)REEMforest algorithm — REEMforest
text: X matrix: Nxp matrix containing p predictors fixed effects, column codes predictor. Y vector: vector containing output trajectories. id vector: vector identifiers different trajectories. Z matrix: Nxq matrix containing q predictor random effects. iter numeric: Maximal number iterations algorithm. default set iter=100 mtry numeric: Number variables randomly sampled candidates split. default value p/3. ntree numeric: Number trees grow. set small number, ensure every input row gets predicted least times. default value ntree=500. time time: vector measurement times associated trajectories Y,Z X. sto character: Defines covariance function stochastic process, can either "none" stochastic process, "BM" Brownian motion, OrnUhl standard Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process, BBridge Brownian Bridge, fbm Fractional Brownian motion; can also function defined user. delta numeric: algorithm stops difference log likelihood two iterations smaller delta. default value set O.O01

title: (S)REEMforest algorithm — REEMforest
text: fitted (S)REEMforest model list following elements: forest: Random forest obtained last iteration. random_effects : Predictions random effects different trajectories. id_btilde: Identifiers individuals associated predictions random_effects. var_random_effects:  Estimation variance covariance matrix random effects. sigma_sto:  Estimation volatility parameter stochastic process. sigma:  Estimation residual variance parameter. time:  vector measurement times associated trajectories Y,Z X. sto:  Stochastic process used model. Vraisemblance: Log-likelihood different iterations. id:  Vector identifiers different trajectories. OOB:  OOB error fitted random forest iteration.

title: (S)REEMforest algorithm — REEMforest
text: (S)REEMforest adaptation random forest regression method longitudinal data introduced Capitaine et. al. (2020) doi:10.1177/0962280220946080. algorithm estimate parameters following semi-parametric stochastic mixed-effects model: $$Y_i(t)=f(X_i(t))+Z_i(t)\beta_i + \omega_i(t)+\epsilon_i$$ \(Y_i(t)\) output time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(X_i(t)\) input predictors (fixed effects) time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(Z_i(t)\) random effects time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(\omega_i(t)\) stochastic process time \(t\) \(\)th individual model serial correlations output measurements; \(\epsilon_i\) residual error.

title: (S)REEMtree algorithm — REEMtree
text: (S)REEMtree adaptation random forest regression method longitudinal data introduced Sela Simonoff. (2012) doi:10.1007/s10994-011-5258-3. algorithm estimate parameters following semi-parametric stochastic mixed-effects model: $$Y_i(t)=f(X_i(t))+Z_i(t)\beta_i + \omega_i(t)+\epsilon_i$$ \(Y_i(t)\) output time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(X_i(t)\) input predictors (fixed effects) time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(Z_i(t)\) random effects time \(t\) \(\)th individual; \(\omega_i(t)\) stochastic process time \(t\) \(\)th individual model serial correlations output measurements; \(\epsilon_i\) residual error.

title: (S)REEMtree algorithm — REEMtree
code: REEMtree(X, Y, id, Z, iter = 10, time, sto, delta = 0.001)

title: (S)REEMtree algorithm — REEMtree
text: X matrix: Nxp matrix containing p predictors fixed effects, column codes predictor. Y vector: vector containing output trajectories. id vector: vector identifiers different trajectories. Z matrix: Nxq matrix containing q predictor random effects. iter numeric: Maximal number iterations algorithm. default set iter=100 time vector: vector measurement times associated trajectories Y,Z X. sto character: Defines covariance function stochastic process, can either "none" stochastic process, "BM" Brownian motion, OrnUhl standard Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process, BBridge Brownian Bridge, fbm Fractional Brownian motion; can also function defined user. delta numeric: algorithm stops difference log likelihood two iterations smaller delta. default value set O.O01

title: (S)REEMtree algorithm — REEMtree
text: fitted (S)MERF model list following elements: forest: Tree obtained last iteration. random_effects : Predictions random effects different trajectories. id_btilde: Identifiers individuals associated predictions random_effects. var_random_effects:  Estimation variance covariance matrix random effects. sigma_sto:  Estimation volatility parameter stochastic process. sigma:  Estimation residual variance parameter. time:  vector measurement times associated trajectories Y,Z X. sto:  Stochastic process used model. Vraisemblance: Log-likelihood different iterations. id:  Vector identifiers different trajectories.

what: Stability score function for (S)MERF and (S)REEMforest methods — Stability_Score
title: Stability score function for (S)MERF and (S)REEMforest methods — Stability_Score
Stability score function for (S)MERF and (S)REEMforest methods — Stability_Score
code: Stability_Score(   X,   Y,   Z,   id,   time,   mtry,   ntree,   sto = "BM",   method = "MERF",   eta = c(1:ncol(X)),   nvars = c(1:ncol(X)) )

title: Stability score function for (S)MERF and (S)REEMforest methods — Stability_Score
text: X matrix: Nxp matrix containing p predictors fixed effects, column codes predictor. Y vector: vector containing output trajectories. Z matrix: Nxq matrix containing q predictor random effects. id vector: vector identifiers different trajectories. time vector: vector measurement times associated trajectories Y,Z X. mtry numeric: Number variables ramdomly picked split node. ntree numeric: Number trees RF. sto string: Defines covariance function stochastic process, can either "none" stochastic process, "BM" Brownian motion, OrnUhl standard Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process, BBridge Brownian Bridge, fbm Fractional Brownian motion; can also function defined user. method string: Defines method used, can either "MERF" "REEMforest". eta numeric: size neighborhood stability score. Can vector, case, returns stability scores corresponding values vector. nvars numeric: number variables consider among impotant variables. Can vector, case, function returns stability scores corresponding values vector.

title: Stability score function for (S)MERF and (S)REEMforest methods — Stability_Score
text: matrix stability scores corresponding eta nvars values. $$th row corresponds $$th value eta $$th column corresponds $$ value nvars.

what: Predict with longitudinal trees and random forests. — predict.longituRF
title: Predict with longitudinal trees and random forests. — predict.longituRF
Predict with longitudinal trees and random forests. — predict.longituRF
code: # S3 method for longituRF predict(object, X, Z, id, time, ...)

title: Predict with longitudinal trees and random forests. — predict.longituRF
text: object : longituRF output (S)MERF; (S)REEMforest; (S)MERT (S)REEMtree function. X matrix: matrix fixed effects new observations predicted. Z matrix: matrix random effects new observations predicted. id vector: vector identifiers new observations predicted. time vector: vector time measurements new observations predicted. ... : low levels arguments.

title: Predict with longitudinal trees and random forests. — predict.longituRF
Predict with longitudinal trees and random forests. — predict.longituRF
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(123) data <- DataLongGenerator(n=20) # Generate the data composed by n=20 individuals. REEMF <- REEMforest(X=data$X,Y=data$Y,Z=data$Z,id=data$id,time=data$time,mtry=2,ntree=500,sto="BM") #> [1] "stopped after 32 iterations." # Then we predict on the learning sample : pred.REEMF <- predict(REEMF, X=data$X,Z=data$Z,id=data$id, time=data$time) # Let's have a look at the predictions # the predictions are in red while the real output trajectories are in blue: par(mfrow=c(4,5),mar=c(2,2,2,2)) for (i in unique(data$id)){   w <- which(data$id==i)   plot(data$time[w],data$Y[w],type="l",col="blue")   lines(data$time[w],pred.REEMF[w], col="red") }  # Train error : mean((pred.REEMF-data$Y)^2) #> [1] 0.2356446  # The same function can be used with a fitted SMERF model: smerf <-MERF(X=data$X,Y=data$Y,Z=data$Z,id=data$id,time=data$time,mtry=2,ntree=500,sto="BM") #> [1] "stopped after 12 iterations." pred.smerf <- predict(smerf, X=data$X,Z=data$Z,id=data$id, time=data$time) # Train error : mean((pred.smerf-data$Y)^2) #> [1] 0.2342153 # This function can be used even on a MERF model (when no stochastic process is specified) merf <-MERF(X=data$X,Y=data$Y,Z=data$Z,id=data$id,time=data$time,mtry=2,ntree=500,sto="none") #> [1] "stopped after 5 iterations." pred.merf <- predict(merf, X=data$X,Z=data$Z,id=data$id, time=data$time) # Train error : mean((pred.merf-data$Y)^2) #> [1] 0.3772968  # }
